author: {'steamid': '76561198005150291', 'num_games_owned': 1963, 'num_reviews': 141, 'playtime_forever': 433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 433, 'playtime_at_review': 433, 'last_played': 1709860515}
review:
[i]I was overjoyed to see another game delivering a similar experience as Total War. While not as polished and refined (which speaks volumes), it is enjoyable. With enough time and care, this could become one of the greats in the tactical warfare genre.[/i]

[h1]ğŸ“ Main Pros, Cons, and Suggestions:[/h1] 
 
ğŸŸ© Pros: 

+  Story mode (acting as a campaign and tutorial) along with 4 Campaigns (acting as scenarios)
+ Story is delivered via brilliantly drawn & narrated scenes in visual novel format 
+ Unit customisation (can manufacture weapons and armour)
+ The music fits the setting perfectly

ğŸŸ¥ Cons:

-	Tutorial initially loaded bugged, with text being covered by a dropdown menu and failure to generate the main quest
-	No auto resolve for battles, which is annoying as combat is shallow due to ranged units overpowering everything
-	UI can be improved greatly e.g. Clicking â€˜Xâ€™ to advance tutorial doesnâ€™t close prior text boxes, please fix this
-	Limited graphical options in the settings menu (can only change resolution and overall quality)
-	No easy way to access tech tree
-	Lack of diplomacy interactions

ğŸ·ï¸ Suggestions: 

~ Additional factions
~ Larger army counts
~ Advanced graphical options (helps with performance issues)
~ Additional hotkeys (end turn, move to next idle army, open tech tree)
~ Different text colour and larger font size in the menu for greater accessibility
~ Improve localisation (despite English settings, some icons/text still appear in Chinese)
~ Once a tech is unlocked, take me to the tech tree so I can immediately begin my next research

[h1]A less refined, Eastern take on Total War[/h1]

First things first, the game starts in Chinese (English is available). Unfortunately, the cutscenes are also in Chinese with no English dubbing, (there are English subtitles). Finally, some aspects of the UI are in Chinese, thankfully none of which hinder gameplay.

Ancient Warfare: The Han Dynastyâ€™s gameplay mirrors that of the TW franchise, so fans of that franchise will feel right at home. The Eastern setting, the beautifully drawn artwork, harmonious music, and themes at play come together to deliver a captivating experience. It is a game all fans of the genre should experience, or at least follow/wishlist.

While I did have fun with Ancient Warfare: The Han Dynasty, there is a lot which can be improved. Being in Early Access, issues are expected, thankfully none which I experienced were game breaking. In saying that, the game is plagued with questionable design decisions.

[h1]My biggest issues[/h1]

Firstly, the tech tree is cumbersome to access - There is no in game icon or hotkey to view it. To view the tree, I had to select my city, select a building (granted it was one which I couldnâ€™t upgrade). The game would advise me that I didnâ€™t meet the prerequisite, and only then allow me to bring up the tech tree.

Secondly, combat is filled with special effects (General abilities, on hit effects and blood splatter) which take away from the serious tone of the game â€“ This may be an issue for some. Secondly, ranged units are broken and negate all difficulty â€“ They need to be reworked. I never needed more than a handful of melee units to act as a meat shield for my ranged units while they annihilated everything.

Please donâ€™t let my long list of cons (or negative comments) turn you away. While itâ€™s rough around the edges, good things take time, and what the small team of developers have already delivered is nothing short of amazing. If you are interested in Chinese history or the TW franchise, Ancient Warfare: The Han Dynasty is a brilliant experience and will scratch that itch.

[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32732116-IndieGems/]Follow our curator page: [b]IndieGems[/b] if you like and want to see more reviews like this one.[/url][/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561198023312533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5310, 'last_played': 1706761231}
review:
After seeing everything it has to offer, I cannot recommend this game at the moment.

I will list some of the points I took into account.

Pros:

-Unit customization: This is by far the best point in the game. 
Any unit can be any unit, you have complete control over the equipment of every unit, which in turn determines what the unit is: spear, two hand sword, sword and shield, archer, crossbow, or javelin. You can then add a horse to make the unit cav if you wish, other than two hand sword or javelin, which are unmounted only.
This also means you can potentially create a unit before having the ability to recruit it outright, since crafting of all items necessary for a unit are unlocked when researching the unit, e.g.: unlock tier 2 sword cav before unlocking tier 2 sword and shield, produce tier 2 swords, armor and footwear (a few turns), and equip on a high level tier 1 archer: 1 turn later you have a high level tier 2 sword and shield.

-Recruitment: An extension of the previous pro.
You only need to worry about what unit you are recruiting before you start producing a steady stream of tier 2 gear, before moving to tier 3 gear.
Once you have a good production and inventory of items, recruitment consists of purchasing the cheapest unit and equipping it as necessary. You can never recruit more than one unit on any turn in any city, so creating armies is not some immediate endeavour either, which would require urgency of choice; regardless, higher tier units take more than one turn to produce outright, whereas equipping a low tier unit takes one turn.

-The map: the actual geography when pitted against the strategic value of bottlenecking a position.
Every location on the map has the potential to become a bulwark with a little conquest.
This means you can withstand more wars, being able to defend multiple fronts with one army.
There is also a good third of the map that is no man's land, some of it crossable with no malus, some of it not crossable at all.
If the AI was worth anything, this might be a very interesting part of the game, since armies could traverse the map in uninhabited territory to attack the rear of a kingdom. As it is, it's just an interesting feature, since the ai doesn't know how to use it and you don't need to based on all the other weaknesses of the AI.

The setting: Ancient China, only not Ancient China, and much earlier than Rotk, not so steeped in the literary myth.
While frustratingly placed, resource spread does a good job to make the player understand the importance of the location to the Han at the time, even though it was never really maintained as Sino for long. It is mostly the areas of what is now known as Tajikistan and Kyrgystan.
For you, the player, there is fierce pressure on obtaining and maintaining iron deposits, since without iron, you cannot craft tier 2 or 3 gear. The story mode helps you pinpoint iron deposits for any of the scenarios.
Includes a sanbox scenario, with each faction starting with one territory, but there aren't enough minor factions to properly take advantage of the scenario, nor is the ai capable enough to do anything with even what it has.

Cons:

Combat: Buy archers, buy a small wall of melee, go into combat and let the enemy meander their way into your arrows, win. Combat is shallow, despite a line up that is interesting. While you want to see what you can do, your best choice is to have ranged units form at least 10 of your units, for a full 16, +2 general average army.
you will never be able to field more than 22 units, +2 generals.
You may, at times, face armies with 80 units in one army. No idea how the AI does it, you can't, not that it matters, since you can kill all of them by overwhelming the enemy with arrows and bolts.

AI management: This is horrible and determines the "do not recommend" on it's own.
The AI does not manage it's towns. Units cost pop to recruit and money to maintain. Buildings cost money, time and wood to build and wood and at times money and/or food to maintain. pop can work in certain buildings to increase productivity.
The AI pumps it's entire balance into units, depleting it's towns of pop and builds public order buildings that give a standing garrison only when the town has a certain population. 
Almost every city of the AI runs a deficit the entire game. At most, I have seen a city profit of about 60 gold, when I have cities making 2-4k gold; never a profit of wood, I have multiple cities of 2k+, you get the idea.
When I conquer an AI town out of boredom, I dismantle all the public order buildings, which are all they built, or some fisheries, which are pointless.

Buildings: So many pointless choices.
Grapes are a resource produced by a building. A resource whose only purpose is to serve in the production of another building that produces gold, but only if supplied by the aforementioned building.
Sigh. This is useless. Fisheries are the same. Fish only serve to supply a fish market for gold, they are not food.
If I need two buildings to make gold, then why not just produce two gold producing buildings?
You could, for example, have grapes produce wine, wine produces morale in dispatched units. Every turn, you lose as many amphora of wine as you have dispatched units. It would be good to choose whether or not you sell off excess wine, but even if it were auto sell off excess not needed by units dispatched, it would still be of use, because right now, grape production to wine serves only to make gold, which outcome is better served by almost any other available building. 
Same for fish, which happen to be something the AI apparently does sometimes build, insanely, since it just builds the fisheries, which harvest the useless fish and never the market which uses those fish for something, namely gold.
It's really a mess in this and the AI is nonexistent.
I don't even want to attack any of them and they can't get out of a spiral of bankruptcy. I keep subsidising them and they keep wasting it on getting another few units from cities with 2 pop.

How Generals function: This is unclear and not well thought out.
None of the attributes matter vis a vis how many units a general can command, this is determined by the title, which, at most is protector of the western regions, for 22 max units, not counting generals, for the single army. So at most 22 + 2 generals.
Only the main general's attributes make a difference to the competence of the units in battle. Unfortunate. The AI can potentially muster (in specific circumstances at the moment) 4 times as many as you can at max, and has the ability to field multiple generals, so why not have a main general whose stats add 100% of their benefit to the army, with the vice General adding 50% of his stats, for example.
General unit specs are horrible. There are far too many generals with specs favouring horses, which are useless under the current AI of head for the centre of the player's line at all costs. There are also a lot of Generals that have multiple same unit, same tier specs on their tree. Generals with 3 times tier 1 spec of crossbow cav, for example, are not uncommon enough that if you play the game to the end of the research tree and hire generals as possible, you will not have one. I'd wager you'd have a few in fact.

The Kushan invasion:
End game crises can be fun and useful to shake things up, but the Kushan is not that.
The numbers are not properly calculated to begin with. I have defeated all but two armies for a total of 48%, with two other kingdoms taking out the two other armies for 4 and 6% each, invasion finished and that was it, 58% of the Kushan invasion existed, the other 42% never spawned, sigh.
They also rip through the AI's unmanaged cities. Their cities have no value anyway, so their destruction actually helps the AI by reducing costs they can't afford anyway, but the only reason their cities are so bad is because the AI doesn't do anything with cities anyway.

Can't recommend

review: Really good Chinese-history TW-style game without the BS from TW Three Kingdoms. Lots of potential and the dev team definitely needs some support taking us to fruition. Honestly I'd play this so much more if there's a free-play/custom battle mode, sometimes I don't want to go through the grind of a campaign.

author: {'steamid': '76561197962745048', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 105, 'last_played': 1701542287}
review: Very impressive game. It reminds me of Shogun Total War, same vibe, same excitement. Graphics etc can always be improved later. But the vibe and game setting / sounds effects are of high quality. Total recommend. I hope CA top management takes note how a massive -scale strategy game should feel and play (again).

author: {'steamid': '76561198007393417', 'num_games_owned': 100, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 683, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 369, 'last_played': 1699635851}
review:
As a "refugee" from Total War: Three Kingdoms, I will try not to be biased against or for and give you... THE TRUTH!

This game is NOT as refined as TW TK and currently does not compare, despite the many problems TW TK has. HOWEVER... it is a very good game, especially considering it's price. There definitely needs a lot of work done on translation, some game mechanics and expansion of the map and playable factions, diplomacy, combat, etc... It's not exceptional and it's not great... but it is a Very Good beginning, and like a newly seeded  tree, it clearly needs nurturing and time to grow.

The Artwork is DAMN FINE though... like Gawd Daaamn son, these cats know how to draw. The OST is really nice too. Definitely has my backing. Looks a little confusing at the start, but give it a little effort and research and you just might like it (if your into Chinese and Turkic-Mongolian history based around China.

For the shorts:
Graphics, 4/10
Sound: 7/10
Art: 9/10
Mechanics: 4/10
Gameplay: 5/10

Despite it being early access or whatever. This might change.

gotta repurchase later once the game is completed.

Overall, this is a decent game with a lot of potential. It's similar to the Total War series, and it's great to see a new competitor in this genre (like the Ultimate General series)

Even though it's still in early access, the game is playable and enjoyable. However, there are some issues that need to be addressed:

1. Ranged units are currently overpowered, while melee units are difficult to control effectively. Better balance between unit types is needed.
2. Unit placement can be tricky at times. (especially when wall exist). (PS. I'm not sure why there is a timer)
3. The attack range indicator for Ranged unit on high ground seems glitchy (its literally floating). 

With some polish and tweaks, this game could become an excellent addition to the tactical warfare genre. The core of solid gameplay is there, but balancing and quality changes would go a long way.

This is a VERY very engaging game with good story telling. I played by changing the menu to english and listening to the story in Chinese.  Didn't know the history of china in that era so is very interesting to know more .

Game play wise for story mode. very engaging teach's you the mechanics of the game.
Story wise very engaging story told.

going to try the campaign mode. VERY VERY good game please keep up the good work.
Would love to see the same type of game but different ERA of china

author: {'steamid': '76561197983571673', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1695934853}
review:
Cool game with a lot of potential 

very unpolished at the moment, to much new information coming at you at once in tutorial. 

1: New information presented
2: Dialogue box + Talking 
3: Quest pop ups 

ALL AT THE SAME TIME, gets a little annoying after a bit and overshadows the learning aspect of the game which should be enjoyable. Don't really want to play it anymore after an hour so I'll wish list it and possibly come back to it later after further development.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041009436', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1695841265}
review:
*The game does not start in English. Voicing is all in mandarin and you need to dig through the menus which are also written in Chinese to switch the text/subtitles to English. Not a con really but something to be aware of.\

It's off brand Total War featuring sound effects (and possibly other assets) ripped directly from the CA title. I played for twelve minutes, was introduced to the story and fought one battle...

There's A LOT, going on just with the UI alone. For the most part, it plays very similarly to Total War but has that distinct..."flair".. to it. ( not necessarily a good or bad thing) There were some features that looked very interesting such as the ability to outfit your units specifically with different types of gear/equipment, the use of terrain advantages being a focus, and a unique hotbar type unit skill feature that I'm sure would be interesting to play around with. 

At this time though I can't really proceed with the game. Localisation isn't really there for the moment and it throws a lot at you (in mandarin) that makes it difficult to want to sit and commit more to for western audiences. 

The art, is beautiful for sure. The music was fun but kind of sporadic, and I did really appreciate a well narrated/visual novel type approach to the story.
